title: 108_hr3433
content: The curr_chunk is a section titled "PURPOSES AND DEFINITIONS." The Act aims to transfer jurisdiction of certain Federal lands in Missouri to the Secretary of Agriculture for the operation of the Mingo Job Corps Civilian Conservation Center. It also clarifies that the Secretary of Labor's role regarding the Job Corps Center remains unchanged. Definitions include the Center being located in Stoddard County, Missouri, and an eligible employee being a current Federal employee at the Center. The Mingo Job Corps Civilian Conservation Center, located in Stoddard County, Missouri, has employees from the Fish and Wildlife Service and two fully funded Washington Office Job Corps support staff. Environmental Authorities refer to laws related to human health, natural resources, and the environment, such as the Clean Air Act and the Toxic Substances Control Act. The curr_chunk provides definitions for various terms related to environmental laws and agencies, including the Toxic Substances Control Act, Safe Drinking Water Act, National Environmental Policy Act, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service, and Job Corps. The curr_chunk defines terms related to environmental laws and agencies, including the National Forest System and National Wildlife Refuge System. The curr_chunk states: "SEC. 2. TRANSFER OF ADMINISTRATION." The Mingo Job Corps Civilian Conservation Center in Stoddard County, Missouri is transferred from the Secretary of the Interior to the Secretary of Agriculture without consideration. Maps and legal descriptions are available for public inspection, and the transfer must be completed within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, will file a legal description and map of the lands being transferred to the Committee on Resources and the Committee on Environment and Public Works. The Center will be administered by the Secretary of Agriculture and subject to National Forest System laws and regulations. The lands being transferred to the Committee on Resources and the Committee on Environment and Public Works will be subject to National Forest System laws and regulations, without conflicting with Job Corps laws. The lands being transferred to the Committee on Resources and the Committee on Environment and Public Works will be subject to National Forest System laws and regulations. The Secretary of Agriculture shall notify the Secretary of the Interior if the Center is no longer used for Job Corps purposes, allowing the Secretary of the Interior 180 days to decide on reassuming jurisdiction over the lands. Reversion will be executed through a Letter of Transfer without Congress involvement. The Forest Service can continue permits granted by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service at the Center, with the ability to reissue or terminate them. They can also take over contracts from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The Forest Service can assume obligations of contracts from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service at the Center. Any contract disputes prior to the enactment of this Act will be handled by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The Chief, Forest Service, and the Director, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, can enter into a memorandum of agreement for implementation procedures. The Forest Service will handle the transfer of employees, property, records, roads, and other issues from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to the Forest Service. The Forest Service will also take on existing agreements with the Secretary of Labor and be responsible for any future agreements or amendments. The Forest Service will have access to all records of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service related to the management of the Center, including personnel records of transferred employees and land title records. Federally owned personal property at the Center will be transferred to the Forest Service without consideration. The Forest Service will dispose of personal property acquired by the Fish and Wildlife Service in accordance with specified procedures. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will provide an inventory of all property and facilities at the Center to the Forest Service, including buildings and office furniture. The Forest Service may exclude movable property from transfer to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service if it is needed for their mission, cannot be replaced cost-effectively, and is not needed for Center management. SEC. 4. COMPLIANCE WITH ENVIRONMENTAL AUTHORITIES. Within 60 days of enactment, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service must provide documentation on the environmental condition of the land to the Forest Service and the Office of Job Corps. Additional information must be shared as it becomes available. Within 120 days of enactment, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will assess the Center's environmental condition and determine necessary actions under ASTM Standard E1527. If required, a memorandum of agreement will be established with the Forest Service for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to perform the necessary actions. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will provide documentation to the Forest Service and the Department of Labor within 180 days of completing the environmental assessment to show compliance with Environmental Authorities for protecting human health and the environment from hazardous substances. The transfer of the Center and its responsibilities under Environmental Authorities will not affect the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's liabilities. The Forest Service is not liable for any environmental matters at the Center. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service or the Department of Labor will not be liable for any environmental issues at the Center occurring before the enactment of this Act, including costs for response actions under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act. The Forest Service's responsibilities and liabilities under environmental authorities are not affected by this title, except as provided in paragraph (3). Other Federal agencies conducting operations at the Center are responsible for costs related to corrective actions and remediation for violations of environmental authorities. SEC. 5. PERSONNEL. Employees from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will transfer to the Forest Service without a break in Federal service, retaining all benefits and eligibility. Employees transferring to the Forest Service will maintain their benefits, leave time, competitive employment status, and grade level/pay. They will also retain their status with CSRS or FERS. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the Forest Service will cover their own implementation costs for this Act. Appropriations will be made as necessary to carry out the Act.
